conclusion: Two charged particles (+q and -q) of mass m each are connected by a massless rod of length d.
The system is initially rotating with angular velocity ω0 about its center of mass, which is at the origin.
The dipole is in a uniform magnetic field B perpendicular to the XY-plane (pointing into the page).
We need to determine the minimum ω0 (ωmin) required for the dipole to reverse its orientation.
The magnetic moment μ of the dipole is given by μ = qd k.
The torque τ due to the magnetic field is τ = μ × B = qd B (-j).
The magnitude of the torque is τ = qdB.
The moment of inertia I of the dipole about its center of mass is I = 1/2 md^2.
Initially, the angular momentum L0 of the dipole is L0 = I ω0 k = 1/2 md^2 ω0 k.
For the dipole to reverse its orientation, it must rotate by π radians.
The work done by the magnetic torque to achieve this is Wτ = qdBπ.
The change in rotational kinetic energy is ΔK = I ω0^2.
Equating the work done by the magnetic torque and the change in kinetic energy gives qdBπ = I ω0^2.
Solving for ω0 gives ω0 = sqrt(2qBπ/md).
The minimum initial angular velocity ωmin required for the dipole to reverse its orientation is ωmin = sqrt(2qBπ/md).
